awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coupled Explicit Thermodynamics of Plasticity - An Innovative Model for Twinning Crystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Most metallic materials are polycrystalline in nature and behave as aggregate composites of single crystals as the basic building block. Metallic materials generally deform elastically by atomic bond distortion or plastically by atomic bond rearrangement. Plastic deformation takes place by the mechanisms of dislocation motion and deformation twinning. Dislocations are atom sized features which move by applied stress and have been relatively well studied and are described by many advanced theories. Deformation twins are single crystal sized features and are not well understood or represented by theories of deformation. This award supports fundamental study of deformation twinning and overcoming limitations to modeling of this plasticity mechanism. The new knowledge and computational capability will have a broad range of applications to advanced manufacturing, structure survivability, and transportation. In addition, the project will support the education of graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of computational micromechanics, materials science, and crystal plasticity. The collaborative nature of the award will also afford the students the opportunity to engage across the two campuses.

Plasticity in metallic materials is mediated by both dislocation slip and deformation twinning. The disparity in characteristic length between the two mechanisms is a limitation to crystal plasticity finite element simulation of polycrystals as deformation twins cannot be represented by volume average. The objective of this project is to develop a computational framework for the explicit representation of deformation twins based upon an embedded weak discontinuity technique. The embedded weak discontinuity is driven by single crystal theory which accounts for twin nucleation, propagation, and growth within a consistent thermodynamic and physical basis. Dislocation slip will also be represented with a thermally activated based theory and will allow slip to occur in both twinned and untwinned regions. The interaction of dislocations with the twin boundaries will also be modelled during the twin growth phase. This project will focus upon the model material of high-purity titanium. Validation experiments will be conducted on large grain samples to allow for detailed characterization. These deformation experiments will be conducted at different initial temperatures and sample temperatures will be measured during deformation to evaluate the model prediction of the Taylor-Quinney factor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The activities of this NSF project included three main projects:  a project on the formation and growth of twin embryos, a second one on thermomechanical modeling, and a final one on slip-assisted twin lamella expansion. These projects provide insightful calculations and analytical models that will be incorporated into CeTOP, a large-scale computational framework for deformation twinning being built at the University of Wisconsin.

 

The first project concerns how twin embryos grow in grain boundaries. The key outcome of this project is the prediction that thickness of the embryo within the grain boundary plane needs to be of sufficient size before it can propagate into the crystal. This thickness is submicron and hence detectable by microscopy. It dispels conventional thought that believed that once a nanoscale twin embryo forms in the grain boundary, it propagates into and across the crystal and it reaches submicron thicknesses by sequentially emitting a twinning dislocation from the grain boundary one layer at a time. The project further reveals that when the thick twin embryo proceeds to propagate into the crystal that it forms a wedge shape. The findings can benefit future microscopy analyses of twins in deformed Ti alloys by indicating which grain boundaries twins originated and which ones are termination points. The prediction from this project implies that twins will be relatively thick at the grain boundary of origin and relatively thin at the grain boundary of termination.  This knowledge means less reliance on in-situ microscopy, which can be challenging for fast moving twins, and benefits microstructure design to promote or hinder deformation twinning.

 

The second project focuses developing a model to predict the response of a material under complicated temperature and mechanical boundary conditions. Two key outcomes arose from this project. First, we built a fully coupled large strain thermomechanical crystal plasticity model for calculation of mechanical and temperature fields in a 3D polycrystalline material. The model is innovative in its account for thermal through the kinematic description, the single crystal constitutive law and the coupled governing equations. Second, with the model, we showed for the first time the evolving strain rate due to thermal cycling. We further proved microplasticity taking place at early stages of thermal cycling even in the macroscopic thermoelastic regime and without applied mechanical deformation. Thermal cycling alone can be enough to provoke dislocation density evolution, particularly at regions with microstructural constraints such as grain boundaries and triple junctions. The model can benefit metal process design, especially where large strains and/or large temperature changes are involved, such as bulk forming and additive manufacturing. 

 

The last project aims to understand the relationship between thermally activated slip and twin expansion under stress and temperature. The main outcome from this project is the development of a 3D slip assisted twin formation model. The model considers three possible consequences of the interaction between a dislocation loop and twin boundary plane, with dissociation reactions being only one of them. The other two interaction mechanisms are cross slip by screw dislocations and climb for edge dislocations. Only the dissociation mechanism leads to production of the twinning partial loops that can glide on the twin boundary and contribute directly to twin growth. For each possible interaction mechanism, the model takes into account kinetic, geometric and energetic considerations. Importantly, temperature-dependent twin growth is suggested by the model in two ways:  by introducing the energetics of three competing mechanisms and via representing the glide of a twinning partial on the twin boundary as a thermally activated process. This model can be directly incorporated into a crystal plasticity CeTOP framework.   

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2024
Modified by: Irene J Beyerlein
